text: we're not alone even at home even if
nobody else is at home it turns out when
we go to sleep our warmth and our bodies
in the beautiful moisture we breathe out
brings waking up in our bed in our
pillows dust mites no these aren't the
horrible bedbugs that you're kind of
scared of staying in the cheap hotel
they're they're microscopic you can't
see with the naked eye but if you look
closely with the microscope they look
like armored personnel carriers with
legs on their big armored hulks down
there and there's thousands of them tens
of thousands they found been found in
the cleanest events everywhere nice
middle-class homes in Scandinavia again
not just in a in cheap hotels and these
might they depend on us we're like God
to them from our bodies come nourishing
incubating moisture and warmth so when
we get into the bed they look up into
the heavens and also food comes now like
manna from heaven coming down to Moses
leading the Hebrews across the Sinai
desert because our skin flakes off big
chunks of our skin we can't see it again
it's microscopic it's the sort of stuff
you see sometimes balled up on a towel
after you tie yourself down after a
shower
thousands these flakes come off and they
float down from the sky to the dust
mites in our pillows that in our
mattresses the dust mites leaned their
heads up and they chomp and they chew
and they're very happy but then in the
warning after our LARM clock goes off we
leave them we leave them behind in these
poor souls it gets colder and chilly
some of the theologians might wonder
where the deity had fed them has gone
and they sort of slow down until we come
back at night again and then they're
happy
